fact: DAPI fluoresces blue and binds strongly to DNA, making it a nuclear stain in fluorescence microscopy.
GFP fluoresces green and is often used to label lysosomes or other cytoplasmic proteins.
Rhodamine fluoresces red and is commonly used to stain mitochondria or lysosomes due to pH sensitivity.
Healthy cells have uniform fluorescence, intact nuclei, and extended filamentous mitochondria.
Apoptotic cells often show punctate fluorescence, fragmented nuclei, and reduced dye signal from photobleaching.
Photobleaching appears as a loss of fluorescence intensity and may indicate damage or cell death.
Lysosomes under fluorescence appear as small, bright green puncta when labeled with GFP or Alexa488.
A cell undergoing apoptosis often displays condensed chromatin and membrane blebbing.
Morphological changes like blebbing, puncta, or nuclear fragmentation signal apoptotic processes.
Puncta indicate organelle clustering or protein aggregation, often seen in stressed or dying cells.
Filamentous structures usually indicate healthy mitochondria or cytoskeletal elements.
If most cells display puncta rather than filamentous structure, widespread apoptosis may be occurring.
You can estimate the number of dying cells by identifying those with fragmented or condensed nuclei.
Viral infection can cause cytoplasmic swelling, lysosomal rupture, and mitochondrial fragmentation.
Viruses enter cells and disrupt organelle function, especially affecting the ER, lysosomes, and mitochondria.
Heavily punctate green staining co-localized with blue nuclear damage often indicates late-stage apoptosis or viral invasion.
During apoptosis, lysosomes may release enzymes into the cytoplasm, leading to degradation of cellular components.
Apoptotic bodies form when dying cells fragment into membrane-bound vesicles containing organelles or chromatin.
Hoechst and DAPI are blue dyes that both bind DNA and highlight nuclear morphology.
Alexa Fluor 488 is a green dye that can target lysosomal proteins and produce punctate fluorescence.
Loss of structural continuity in the nucleus under fluorescence is a hallmark of apoptotic nuclear fragmentation.
Viral invasion may trigger lysosomal destabilization, visible as an increase in green puncta and nuclear damage.
In advanced apoptosis, the nucleus becomes irregular or fragmented and surrounded by clustered lysosomes.
If four or more cells show blebbing or nuclear fragmentation in a fluorescent image, widespread cell death is likely.
Merged fluorescent images often show nuclei (blue), lysosomes (green), and mitochondria (red) to differentiate compartments.
Blue-stained, round nuclei with minimal green puncta suggest healthy, non-apoptotic cells.
Disorganized green puncta with irregular blue nuclear shapes suggest apoptotic or infected cells.
Apoptotic cells shrink and may appear isolated with brighter, punctate staining.
Virus-induced apoptosis can alter the morphology of the nucleus and cause lysosomal clustering.
Healthy cells typically have smooth, oval nuclei and diffuse green fluorescence.
In healthy cells, the nucleus is typically round or oval in shape and centrally located within the cytoplasm.
The nucleus of healthy cells should show a distinct, clear boundary with a uniform blue fluorescence when stained with DAPI or other nuclear stains.
Healthy cells exhibit a single, intact nucleus. An increase in the number of nuclei or fragmented nuclei often indicates cellular stress or damage.
In healthy cells, mitochondria are distributed throughout the cytoplasm, forming a network that can appear punctate or tubular under fluorescence microscopy.
Healthy mitochondrial staining using Mitotracker Red or similar dyes shows distinct, vibrant red fluorescence, indicating normal mitochondrial function.
Healthy cells typically maintain a normal, consistent size and shape, with no excessive swelling or shrinkage.
A healthy cell will have a clear cytoplasm with visible organelles, such as mitochondria and the nucleus. The cytoplasm will not show signs of abnormal vacuolization or excessive stress responses.
In healthy cells, the nucleus appears oval or round and is centrally located in the cell.
A bright, uniform blue fluorescence pattern in the nucleus indicates healthy cells.
In microscopy, healthy cells may exhibit a smooth or slightly ruffled surface without large irregularities or blebs.
